elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st0005">Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0005" view="all">A new organic ligand of 1,2,4,5-tetrakis(3-carboxyphenyl)-benzene (<ce:italic>m</ce:italic>-H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>TCPB) and its first metal–organic framework <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>m</ce:italic>-TCPB)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>·[(DEF)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (DEF<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>N, N′-diethylformamide) was designed and synthesized. <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> has a three-dimensional (4,4) framework topology. The activated <ce:bold>1a</ce:bold> exhibits permanent porosity and demonstrates selective toward adsorption of hydrogen over nitrogen at 77<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K, and acetylene and carbon dioxide over methane at room temperature.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

A new organic ligand of 1,2,4,5-tetrakis(3-carboxyphenyl)-benzene (m-H4TCPB) and its first metal-organic framework 1 [Cu2(m-TCPB)(H2O)2]n⋅[(DEF)3]n (DEF=N, N'-diethylformamide) was designed and synthesized. 1 has a three-dimensional (4,4) framework topology. The activated 1a exhibits permanent porosity and demonstrates selective toward adsorption of hydrogen over nitrogen at 77K, and acetylene and carbon dioxide over methane at room temperature.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st0045">Graphical abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0055" view="all">A new organic ligand of 1,2,4,5-tetrakis(3-carboxyphenyl)-benzene (<ce:italic>m</ce:italic>-H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>TCPB) and its first metal–organic framework <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>m</ce:italic>-TCPB)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>·[(DEF)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (DEF<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>N, N′-diethylformamide) was designed and synthesized. <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> has a three-dimensional (4,4) framework topology. The activated <ce:bold>1a</ce:bold> exhibits permanent porosity and demonstrates selective toward adsorption of hydrogen over nitrogen at 77<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K, and acetylene and carbon dioxide over methane at room temperature.<ce:display>
<ce:figure id="f0020">
<ce:link id="lk0025" locator="fx1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
</ce:display>
</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

A new organic ligand of 1,2,4,5-tetrakis(3-carboxyphenyl)-benzene (m-H4TCPB) and its first metal-organic framework 1 [Cu2(m-TCPB)(H2O)2]n⋅[(DEF)3]n (DEF=N, N'-diethylformamide) was designed and synthesized. 1 has a three-dimensional (4,4) framework topology. The activated 1a exhibits permanent porosity and demonstrates selective toward adsorption of hydrogen over nitrogen at 77K, and acetylene and carbon dioxide over methane at room temperature.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st0015">Highlights</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0060" view="all">
<ce:list id="l0005">
<ce:list-item id="u0005">
<ce:label>•</ce:label>
<ce:para id="p0050" view="all">Synthesis of a copper-based MOF constructed from a new tetracarboxylic acid linker.</ce:para>
</ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="u0010">
<ce:label>•</ce:label>
<ce:para id="p0055" view="all">The three-dimensional framework was proved by single-crystal X-ray diffraction.</ce:para>
</ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="u0015">
<ce:label>•</ce:label>
<ce:para id="p0060" view="all">Selective gas sorption property was investigated.</ce:para>
</ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="u0020">
<ce:label>•</ce:label>
<ce:para id="p0065" view="all">The coverage-dependent adsorption enthalpies were calculated by the virial method.</ce:para>
</ce:list-item>
</ce:list>
</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Highlights

   ⋅ Synthesis of a copper-based MOF constructed from a new tetracarboxylic acid linker.   ⋅ The three-dimensional framework was proved by single-crystal X-ray diffraction.   ⋅ Selective gas sorption property was investigated.   ⋅ The coverage-dependent adsorption enthalpies were calculated by the virial method.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0050" view="all">Synthesis of a copper-based MOF constructed from a new tetracarboxylic acid linker.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0055" view="all">The three-dimensional framework was proved by single-crystal X-ray diffraction.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0060" view="all">Selective gas sorption property was investigated.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0065" view="all">The coverage-dependent adsorption enthalpies were calculated by the virial method.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0005" view="all">Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are a class of permanently microporous hybrid materials, which exist as infinite crystalline lattice comprising inorganic vertices (metals ions or clusters) and organic struts, connected by coordination bonds . One of the most attractive features of MOFs is the ability to incorporate an unlimited range of organic ligands, as well as their simple synthesis and recent advances in purification . In particular, their extremely high surface areas, ultralow densities, fine tunable pore structures, and adjustable chemical functionality make them promising candidates for gas separation, as well as for catalysis, chemical sensing, and drug delivery .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of a copper-based MOF constructed from a new tetracarboxylic acid linker.

The three-dimensional framework was proved by single-crystal X-ray diffraction.

Selective gas sorption property was investigated.

The coverage-dependent adsorption enthalpies were calculated by the virial method.

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are a class of permanently microporous hybrid materials, which exist as infinite crystalline lattice comprising inorganic vertices (metals ions or clusters) and organic struts, connected by coordination bonds . One of the most attractive features of MOFs is the ability to incorporate an unlimited range of organic ligands, as well as their simple synthesis and recent advances in purification . In particular, their extremely high surface areas, ultralow densities, fine tunable pore structures, and adjustable chemical functionality make them promising candidates for gas separation, as well as for catalysis, chemical sensing, and drug delivery .

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0010" view="all">By carefully choosing metals and organic linkers, the structure and pore properties, such as pore size and pore volume of MOFs, can be systematically tailored . Scores of organic ligands (such as carboxylic acid, imidazole and tetrazole) have been utilized as struts in MOFs . The ligand 1,2,4,5-tetrakis(4-carboxyphenyl)-benzene (<ce:italic>p</ce:italic>-H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>TCPB) was first synthesized and applied in MOFs by Hupp's group. It has distinctive features, such as: (1) four carboxylic groups, which are potential metal biding sites allowing for the formation of a topologically diverse family of materials, (2) its rigidness, which can enable the formation of robust MOFs with metal ions, and (3) its bulky long molecular structure, which can give rise to the formation of microporous coordination frameworks through framework interpenetration, making it suitable for gas storage, separation, and catalysis . With this in mind, we tried to synthesize a copper-based paddlewheel framework using H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>TCPB as the linker, but failed. On the other hand, altering the position of the functional groups (such as carboxylate, sulfonate, phosphonate, and heterocyclic groups) in the ligands can also influence the network formation and porosity . Here, we describe a new Cu-paddlewheel MOFs with the overall formula of [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>m</ce:italic>-TCPB)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>[(DEF)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, which shows intriguing structure and properties, such as H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>/N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> separation.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: By carefully choosing metals and organic linkers, the structure and pore properties, such as pore size and pore volume of MOFs, can be systematically tailored . Scores of organic ligands (such as carboxylic acid, imidazole and tetrazole) have been utilized as struts in MOFs . The ligand 1,2,4,5-tetrakis(4-carboxyphenyl)-benzene (p-H4TCPB) was first synthesized and applied in MOFs by Hupp's group. It has distinctive features, such as: (1) four carboxylic groups, which are potential metal biding sites allowing for the formation of a topologically diverse family of materials, (2) its rigidness, which can enable the formation of robust MOFs with metal ions, and (3) its bulky long molecular structure, which can give rise to the formation of microporous coordination frameworks through framework interpenetration, making it suitable for gas storage, separation, and catalysis . With this in mind, we tried to synthesize a copper-based paddlewheel framework using H4TCPB as the linker, but failed. On the other hand, altering the position of the functional groups (such as carboxylate, sulfonate, phosphonate, and heterocyclic groups) in the ligands can also influence the network formation and porosity . Here, we describe a new Cu-paddlewheel MOFs with the overall formula of [Cu2(m-TCPB)(H2O)2]n ⋅[(DEF)3]n 1, which shows intriguing structure and properties, such as H2/N2 separation.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0015" view="all">
<ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is constructed from 1,2,4,5-tetrakis(3-carboxyphenyl)-benzene (<ce:italic>m</ce:italic>-H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>TCPB) (
<ce:float-anchor refid="sch0005"></ce:float-anchor>), which can be straightforwardly synthesized by the coupling and hydrolysis reaction, from its precursor. A mixture of Cu(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.02<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g) and <ce:italic>m</ce:italic>-H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>TCPB (0.01<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g) was dissolved in N, N′-diethylformamide (DEF, 1.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL), water (0.4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL), and con. HCl (8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μL). The final mixture was placed in a 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL glass vial, which was sealed and heated at 75<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 24<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h, and then cooled to room temperature. Rhombus-shaped turquoise crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> were collected in 42% yield (based on ligand <ce:italic>m</ce:italic>-H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>TCPB). Anal. calcd for C<ce:inf loc="post">49</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">55</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">13</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>: C, 57.64; H, 5.43; and N, 4.12. Found: C, 57.70; H, 5.46; and N, 4.17. IR/cm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup>: 2972 (m), 1615 (m), 1538 (s), 1395 (s), 1371 (s), 820(m), 767 (s), and 710(s). It was formulated on the bases of single-crystal X-ray structure determination, elemental analysis, and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). A single-crystal X-ray crystallographic study revealed that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> crystallizes in the monoclinic system and C2/c space group . As quite frequently observed in MOFs, the framework contains paddle-wheel binuclear {Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(COO)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>} secondary building units (a<ce:float-anchor refid="f0005"></ce:float-anchor>), which are bridged by organic <ce:italic>m</ce:italic>-TCPB ligands to form a two-dimensional (2D) hexagonal grid {Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>m</ce:italic>-TCPB)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>} (b). The adjacent 2D hexagonal grid is packed in parallel, leading to the final porous-containing three-dimensional (3D) frameworks with the cavities of 8.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>12.6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> (d). The structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is non-interpenetrated and the topology (Fig. S2) can be best described as a simple 4, 4 connected net (c, d), which exhibits the same topology as well-established MOFs, such as: MOF-2 Zn(BDC)-(DMF), Cu(BDC-OH), Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(TBAPy), and UTSA-72 . The fifth coordination sites of paddle–wheel Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(COO)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> units were occupied by water molecules, which will be critical for the gas-absorption selectivity. Upon water molecules removal, the open sites will be exposed for other applications. The solvent accessible volume after the removal of the uncoordinated solvents is 59.6% calculated with PLATON .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: 1 is constructed from 1,2,4,5-tetrakis(3-carboxyphenyl)-benzene (m-H4TCPB) ( ), which can be straightforwardly synthesized by the coupling and hydrolysis reaction, from its precursor. A mixture of Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O (0.02g) and m-H4TCPB (0.01g) was dissolved in N, N'-diethylformamide (DEF, 1.5mL), water (0.4mL), and con. HCl (8μL). The final mixture was placed in a 20mL glass vial, which was sealed and heated at 75°C for 24h, and then cooled to room temperature. Rhombus-shaped turquoise crystals of 1 were collected in 42% yield (based on ligand m-H4TCPB). Anal. calcd for C49H55O13N3Cu2: C, 57.64; H, 5.43; and N, 4.12. Found: C, 57.70; H, 5.46; and N, 4.17. IR/cm-1: 2972 (m), 1615 (m), 1538 (s), 1395 (s), 1371 (s), 820(m), 767 (s), and 710(s). It was formulated on the bases of single-crystal X-ray structure determination, elemental analysis, and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). A single-crystal X-ray crystallographic study revealed that 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic system and C2/c space group . As quite frequently observed in MOFs, the framework contains paddle-wheel binuclear {Cu2(COO)4} secondary building units (a), which are bridged by organic m-TCPB ligands to form a two-dimensional (2D) hexagonal grid {Cu2(m-TCPB)2} (b). The adjacent 2D hexagonal grid is packed in parallel, leading to the final porous-containing three-dimensional (3D) frameworks with the cavities of 8.5×12.6Å2 (d). The structure of 1 is non-interpenetrated and the topology (Fig. S2) can be best described as a simple 4, 4 connected net (c, d), which exhibits the same topology as well-established MOFs, such as: MOF-2 Zn(BDC)-(DMF), Cu(BDC-OH), Zn2(TBAPy), and UTSA-72 . The fifth coordination sites of paddle-wheel Cu2(COO)4 units were occupied by water molecules, which will be critical for the gas-absorption selectivity. Upon water molecules removal, the open sites will be exposed for other applications. The solvent accessible volume after the removal of the uncoordinated solvents is 59.6% calculated with PLATON .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0020" view="all">The structure was determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, and the phase purity of the material in bulk amount was confirmed by elemental analysis and powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) (Fig. S3). As shown in Fig. S4, the thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) studies reveal that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> gradually loses the free DEF and coordinated water molecules (obsd. 32.8%, calcd. 33.2%) in the temperature range 25–250<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C to form the desolvated framework <ce:bold>1a</ce:bold>. Typically, the free solvent molecules were lost first followed by the coordinated solvent molecules. However, because DEF has much higher boiling point (153<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C) than water, DEF and coordinated water molecules might be released simultaneously from <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, so we cannot specifically assign the weight loss steps for these two types of solvent molecules from the TGA data. The temperature dependent PXRD patterns further confirm that desolvated framework keeps crystalline nature until 250<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, though the diffraction peaks were slightly broaden and shifted. After gas sorption, <ce:bold>1a</ce:bold> still exhibits a moderately high crystalline nature, indicating that <ce:bold>1a</ce:bold> displays a permanent porous structure.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The structure was determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, and the phase purity of the material in bulk amount was confirmed by elemental analysis and powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) (Fig. S3). As shown in Fig. S4, the thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) studies reveal that 1 gradually loses the free DEF and coordinated water molecules (obsd. 32.8%, calcd. 33.2%) in the temperature range 25-250°C to form the desolvated framework 1a. Typically, the free solvent molecules were lost first followed by the coordinated solvent molecules. However, because DEF has much higher boiling point (153°C) than water, DEF and coordinated water molecules might be released simultaneously from 1, so we cannot specifically assign the weight loss steps for these two types of solvent molecules from the TGA data. The temperature dependent PXRD patterns further confirm that desolvated framework keeps crystalline nature until 250°C, though the diffraction peaks were slightly broaden and shifted. After gas sorption, 1a still exhibits a moderately high crystalline nature, indicating that 1a displays a permanent porous structure.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0025" view="all">To check the selective adsorption properties of <ce:bold>1a</ce:bold>, hydrogen and nitrogen adsorptions were carried out at 77<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K; carbon dioxide, methane, and acetylene adsorptions were carried out at 273<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K and 296<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K, respectively. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>, <ce:bold>1a</ce:bold> can take up a relatively significant amount of hydrogen (24.4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>/g) but a negligible amount of nitrogen (2.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>/g) at 77<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K and 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>atm, underlying a good capacity of <ce:bold>1a</ce:bold> for H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>/N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> separation . <ce:bold>1a</ce:bold> can also absorb 23.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>/g acetylene and 23.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>/g carbon dioxide, but a very limited amount of methane (7.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>/g) at 273<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K and 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>atm (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>). Their adsorption isotherms at 296<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K (Fig. S6) further confirmed the different gas uptakes of <ce:bold>1a</ce:bold> for these examined gas molecules, underlining the potential of these new MOFs for the selective gas separation of C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>/CH<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>, CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>/CH<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: To check the selective adsorption properties of 1a, hydrogen and nitrogen adsorptions were carried out at 77K; carbon dioxide, methane, and acetylene adsorptions were carried out at 273K and 296K, respectively. As shown in  , 1a can take up a relatively significant amount of hydrogen (24.4cm3/g) but a negligible amount of nitrogen (2.3cm3/g) at 77K and 1atm, underlying a good capacity of 1a for H2/N2 separation . 1a can also absorb 23.3cm3/g acetylene and 23.0cm3/g carbon dioxide, but a very limited amount of methane (7.3cm3/g) at 273K and 1atm ( ). Their adsorption isotherms at 296K (Fig. S6) further confirmed the different gas uptakes of 1a for these examined gas molecules, underlining the potential of these new MOFs for the selective gas separation of C2H2/CH4, CO2/CH4.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0030" view="all">The coverage-dependent adsorption enthalpies of <ce:bold>1a</ce:bold> to carbon dioxide, acetylene, and methane were calculated based on the virial method, a well-established and reliable methodology from fits of their adsorption isotherms at 273<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K and 296<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K (Fig. S7) . The enthalpies at zero coverage of gas were calculated to give the values of 38.3, 34.7, and 28.6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>kJ/mol for C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, and CH<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> respectively. The adsorption enthalpies for C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, and CH<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> in <ce:bold>1a</ce:bold> are moderately higher than those reported values . The relatively high <ce:italic>Q<ce:inf loc="post">st</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> of this compound may be due to the pore size and open metal sites in the activated framework, which favors the selective gas separation for these large gas molecules. Henry's law selectivities (<ce:italic>S<ce:inf loc="post">ij</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>) for C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>/CH<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>, CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>/CH<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> calculated respectively based on the equation <ce:italic>S<ce:inf loc="post">ij</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>K<ce:inf loc="post">Hi</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>/<ce:italic>K<ce:inf loc="post">Hj</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>, are also shown in Table S1, which are moderately high .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The coverage-dependent adsorption enthalpies of 1a to carbon dioxide, acetylene, and methane were calculated based on the virial method, a well-established and reliable methodology from fits of their adsorption isotherms at 273K and 296K (Fig. S7) . The enthalpies at zero coverage of gas were calculated to give the values of 38.3, 34.7, and 28.6kJ/mol for C2H2, CO2, and CH4 respectively. The adsorption enthalpies for C2H2, CO2, and CH4 in 1a are moderately higher than those reported values . The relatively high Qst  of this compound may be due to the pore size and open metal sites in the activated framework, which favors the selective gas separation for these large gas molecules. Henry's law selectivities (Sij ) for C2H2/CH4, CO2/CH4 calculated respectively based on the equation Sij  = KHi /KHj , are also shown in Table S1, which are moderately high .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0035" view="all">In conclusion, we synthesized and structurally characterized a new organic linker 1,2,4,5-tetrakis(3-carboxyphenyl)-benzene (<ce:italic>m</ce:italic>-H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>TCPB) and its first metal–organic framework Cu-<ce:italic>m</ce:italic>-TCPB. The activated <ce:bold>1a</ce:bold> demonstrates selective toward adsorption of hydrogen over nitrogen at 77<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K, and acetylene and carbon dioxide over methane at room temperature based on Henry's law gas separation selectivity. We are now exploring ways to assemble this new organic linker with other metal ions/clusters to synthesize diverse structure MOFs and explore their potential applications.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In conclusion, we synthesized and structurally characterized a new organic linker 1,2,4,5-tetrakis(3-carboxyphenyl)-benzene (m-H4TCPB) and its first metal-organic framework Cu-m-TCPB. The activated 1a demonstrates selective toward adsorption of hydrogen over nitrogen at 77K, and acetylene and carbon dioxide over methane at room temperature based on Henry's law gas separation selectivity. We are now exploring ways to assemble this new organic linker with other metal ions/clusters to synthesize diverse structure MOFs and explore their potential applications.

elements.content: <ce:simple-para id="sp0030" view="all">The X-ray diffraction data was collected using synchrotron radiation, λ<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.40663<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, at Advanced Photon Source on beamline 15ID-C. Indexing was performed using APEX2 (difference vectors method). Data integration and reduction were performed using SaintPlus 6.01. Absorption correction was performed by multi-scan method implemented in SADABS. The structure was solved using SHELXL-2014 (direct methods) and refined using SHELXL-2014 (full-matrix least-squares on F<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>) contained packages. Despite of using synchrotron source and trying several crystals from different batches, diffraction experiment resulted in low quality diffraction data. This can be attributed to the presence of the solvent disorder and to the presence of bad quality, multiply twinned crystals. All non-H atoms were found in the difference Fourier map and were refined using the distance restraints. Hydrogen atoms were placed in geometrically calculated positions and included in the refinement process using riding model with isotropic thermal parameters: Uiso(H)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Ueq(–CH). The DEF solvents could not be located. Contributions to scattering from all solvent molecules were removed using the SQUEEZE routine of PLATON; the structure was then refined again using the data. Crystal data for 1: CuC<ce:inf loc="post">17</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">11</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>, Mr<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>358.80, monoclinic, space group C2/c, a<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>17.714(7) Å, b<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>12.567(5) Å, c<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>25.643(9) Å, α<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>90° β<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>93.440(6) γ<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>90° V<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>5698(4) Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>, Z<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>8, Dc<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.836<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>3</ce:sup>, μ<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.412<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup>, T<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>100(2) K, 33107 reflections measured, 2465 independent reflections, final R1[I<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>><ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2σ(I)]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.1194, wR(F2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.2953, GOF<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.074.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text: The X-ray diffraction data was collected using synchrotron radiation, λ=0.40663Å, at Advanced Photon Source on beamline 15ID-C. Indexing was performed using APEX2 (difference vectors method). Data integration and reduction were performed using SaintPlus 6.01. Absorption correction was performed by multi-scan method implemented in SADABS. The structure was solved using SHELXL-2014 (direct methods) and refined using SHELXL-2014 (full-matrix least-squares on F2) contained packages. Despite of using synchrotron source and trying several crystals from different batches, diffraction experiment resulted in low quality diffraction data. This can be attributed to the presence of the solvent disorder and to the presence of bad quality, multiply twinned crystals. All non-H atoms were found in the difference Fourier map and were refined using the distance restraints. Hydrogen atoms were placed in geometrically calculated positions and included in the refinement process using riding model with isotropic thermal parameters: Uiso(H)=1.2Ueq(-CH). The DEF solvents could not be located. Contributions to scattering from all solvent molecules were removed using the SQUEEZE routine of PLATON; the structure was then refined again using the data. Crystal data for 1: CuC17H11O5, Mr=358.80, monoclinic, space group C2/c, a=17.714(7) Å, b=12.567(5) Å, c=25.643(9) Å, α=90° β=93.440(6) γ=90° V=5698(4) Å3, Z=8, Dc=0.836gcm-3, μ=0.412mm-1, T=100(2) K, 33107 reflections measured, 2465 independent reflections, final R1[I>2σ(I)]=0.1194, wR(F2)=0.2953, GOF=1.074.

cln_elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0015" view="all">
<ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is constructed from 1,2,4,5-tetrakis(3-carboxyphenyl)-benzene (<ce:italic>m</ce:italic>-H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>TCPB) (
<ce:float-anchor refid="sch0005"></ce:float-anchor>), which can be straightforwardly synthesized by the coupling and hydrolysis reaction, from its precursor. A mixture of Cu(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.02<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g) and <ce:italic>m</ce:italic>-H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>TCPB (0.01<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g) was dissolved in N, N′-diethylformamide (DEF, 1.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL), water (0.4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL), and con. HCl (8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μL). The final mixture was placed in a 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL glass vial, which was sealed and heated at 75<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 24<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h, and then cooled to room temperature. Rhombus-shaped turquoise crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> were collected in 42% yield (based on ligand <ce:italic>m</ce:italic>-H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>TCPB). Anal. calcd for C<ce:inf loc="post">49</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">55</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">13</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>: C, 57.64; H, 5.43; and N, 4.12. Found: C, 57.70; H, 5.46; and N, 4.17. IR/cm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup>: 2972 (m), 1615 (m), 1538 (s), 1395 (s), 1371 (s), 820(m), 767 (s), and 710(s). It was formulated on the bases of single-crystal X-ray structure determination, elemental analysis, and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). A single-crystal X-ray crystallographic study revealed that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> crystallizes in the monoclinic system and C2/c space group . As quite frequently observed in MOFs, the framework contains paddle-wheel binuclear {Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(COO)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>} secondary building units (a<ce:float-anchor refid="f0005"></ce:float-anchor>), which are bridged by organic <ce:italic>m</ce:italic>-TCPB ligands to form a two-dimensional (2D) hexagonal grid {Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>m</ce:italic>-TCPB)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>} (b). The adjacent 2D hexagonal grid is packed in parallel, leading to the final porous-containing three-dimensional (3D) frameworks with the cavities of 8.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>12.6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> (d). The structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is non-interpenetrated and the topology (Fig. S2) can be best described as a simple 4, 4 connected net (c, d), which exhibits the same topology as well-established MOFs, such as: MOF-2 Zn(BDC)-(DMF), Cu(BDC-OH), Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(TBAPy), and UTSA-72 . The fifth coordination sites of paddle–wheel Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(COO)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> units were occupied by water molecules, which will be critical for the gas-absorption selectivity. Upon water molecules removal, the open sites will be exposed for other applications. The solvent accessible volume after the removal of the uncoordinated solvents is 59.6% calculated with PLATON .</ce:para>
cln_elements.clean_text: 1 is constructed from 1,2,4,5-tetrakis(3-carboxyphenyl)-benzene (m-H4TCPB) ( ), which can be straightforwardly synthesized by the coupling and hydrolysis reaction, from its precursor. A mixture of Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O (0.02g) and m-H4TCPB (0.01g) was dissolved in N, N'-diethylformamide (DEF, 1.5mL), water (0.4mL), and con. HCl (8μL). The final mixture was placed in a 20mL glass vial, which was sealed and heated at 75°C for 24h, and then cooled to room temperature. Rhombus-shaped turquoise crystals of 1 were collected in 42% yield (based on ligand m-H4TCPB). Anal. calcd for C49H55O13N3Cu2: C, 57.64; H, 5.43; and N, 4.12. Found: C, 57.70; H, 5.46; and N, 4.17. IR/cm-1: 2972 (m), 1615 (m), 1538 (s), 1395 (s), 1371 (s), 820(m), 767 (s), and 710(s). It was formulated on the bases of single-crystal X-ray structure determination, elemental analysis, and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). A single-crystal X-ray crystallographic study revealed that 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic system and C2/c space group . As quite frequently observed in MOFs, the framework contains paddle-wheel binuclear {Cu2(COO)4} secondary building units (a), which are bridged by organic m-TCPB ligands to form a two-dimensional (2D) hexagonal grid {Cu2(m-TCPB)2} (b). The adjacent 2D hexagonal grid is packed in parallel, leading to the final porous-containing three-dimensional (3D) frameworks with the cavities of 8.5×12.6Å2 (d). The structure of 1 is non-interpenetrated and the topology (Fig. S2) can be best described as a simple 4, 4 connected net (c, d), which exhibits the same topology as well-established MOFs, such as: MOF-2 Zn(BDC)-(DMF), Cu(BDC-OH), Zn2(TBAPy), and UTSA-72 . The fifth coordination sites of paddle-wheel Cu2(COO)4 units were occupied by water molecules, which will be critical for the gas-absorption selectivity. Upon water molecules removal, the open sites will be exposed for other applications. The solvent accessible volume after the removal of the uncoordinated solvents is 59.6% calculated with PLATON .

cln_elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0020" view="all">The structure was determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, and the phase purity of the material in bulk amount was confirmed by elemental analysis and powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) (Fig. S3). As shown in Fig. S4, the thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) studies reveal that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> gradually loses the free DEF and coordinated water molecules (obsd. 32.8%, calcd. 33.2%) in the temperature range 25–250<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C to form the desolvated framework <ce:bold>1a</ce:bold>. Typically, the free solvent molecules were lost first followed by the coordinated solvent molecules. However, because DEF has much higher boiling point (153<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C) than water, DEF and coordinated water molecules might be released simultaneously from <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, so we cannot specifically assign the weight loss steps for these two types of solvent molecules from the TGA data. The temperature dependent PXRD patterns further confirm that desolvated framework keeps crystalline nature until 250<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, though the diffraction peaks were slightly broaden and shifted. After gas sorption, <ce:bold>1a</ce:bold> still exhibits a moderately high crystalline nature, indicating that <ce:bold>1a</ce:bold> displays a permanent porous structure.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0025" view="all">To check the selective adsorption properties of <ce:bold>1a</ce:bold>, hydrogen and nitrogen adsorptions were carried out at 77<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K; carbon dioxide, methane, and acetylene adsorptions were carried out at 273<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K and 296<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K, respectively. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>, <ce:bold>1a</ce:bold> can take up a relatively significant amount of hydrogen (24.4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>/g) but a negligible amount of nitrogen (2.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>/g) at 77<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K and 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>atm, underlying a good capacity of <ce:bold>1a</ce:bold> for H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>/N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> separation . <ce:bold>1a</ce:bold> can also absorb 23.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>/g acetylene and 23.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>/g carbon dioxide, but a very limited amount of methane (7.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>/g) at 273<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K and 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>atm (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>). Their adsorption isotherms at 296<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K (Fig. S6) further confirmed the different gas uptakes of <ce:bold>1a</ce:bold> for these examined gas molecules, underlining the potential of these new MOFs for the selective gas separation of C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>/CH<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>, CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>/CH<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0030" view="all">The coverage-dependent adsorption enthalpies of <ce:bold>1a</ce:bold> to carbon dioxide, acetylene, and methane were calculated based on the virial method, a well-established and reliable methodology from fits of their adsorption isotherms at 273<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K and 296<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K (Fig. S7) . The enthalpies at zero coverage of gas were calculated to give the values of 38.3, 34.7, and 28.6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>kJ/mol for C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, and CH<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> respectively. The adsorption enthalpies for C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, and CH<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> in <ce:bold>1a</ce:bold> are moderately higher than those reported values . The relatively high <ce:italic>Q<ce:inf loc="post">st</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> of this compound may be due to the pore size and open metal sites in the activated framework, which favors the selective gas separation for these large gas molecules. Henry's law selectivities (<ce:italic>S<ce:inf loc="post">ij</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>) for C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>/CH<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>, CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>/CH<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> calculated respectively based on the equation <ce:italic>S<ce:inf loc="post">ij</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>K<ce:inf loc="post">Hi</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>/<ce:italic>K<ce:inf loc="post">Hj</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>, are also shown in Table S1, which are moderately high .</ce:para><ce:simple-para id="sp0030" view="all">The X-ray diffraction data was collected using synchrotron radiation, λ<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.40663<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, at Advanced Photon Source on beamline 15ID-C. Indexing was performed using APEX2 (difference vectors method). Data integration and reduction were performed using SaintPlus 6.01. Absorption correction was performed by multi-scan method implemented in SADABS. The structure was solved using SHELXL-2014 (direct methods) and refined using SHELXL-2014 (full-matrix least-squares on F<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>) contained packages. Despite of using synchrotron source and trying several crystals from different batches, diffraction experiment resulted in low quality diffraction data. This can be attributed to the presence of the solvent disorder and to the presence of bad quality, multiply twinned crystals. All non-H atoms were found in the difference Fourier map and were refined using the distance restraints. Hydrogen atoms were placed in geometrically calculated positions and included in the refinement process using riding model with isotropic thermal parameters: Uiso(H)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Ueq(–CH). The DEF solvents could not be located. Contributions to scattering from all solvent molecules were removed using the SQUEEZE routine of PLATON; the structure was then refined again using the data. Crystal data for 1: CuC<ce:inf loc="post">17</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">11</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>, Mr<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>358.80, monoclinic, space group C2/c, a<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>17.714(7) Å, b<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>12.567(5) Å, c<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>25.643(9) Å, α<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>90° β<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>93.440(6) γ<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>90° V<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>5698(4) Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>, Z<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>8, Dc<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.836<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>3</ce:sup>, μ<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.412<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup>, T<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>100(2) K, 33107 reflections measured, 2465 independent reflections, final R1[I<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>><ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2σ(I)]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.1194, wR(F2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.2953, GOF<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.074.</ce:simple-para>
cln_elements.clean_text:
The structure was determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, and the phase purity of the material in bulk amount was confirmed by elemental analysis and powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) (Fig. S3). As shown in Fig. S4, the thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) studies reveal that 1 gradually loses the free DEF and coordinated water molecules (obsd. 32.8%, calcd. 33.2%) in the temperature range 25-250°C to form the desolvated framework 1a. Typically, the free solvent molecules were lost first followed by the coordinated solvent molecules. However, because DEF has much higher boiling point (153°C) than water, DEF and coordinated water molecules might be released simultaneously from 1, so we cannot specifically assign the weight loss steps for these two types of solvent molecules from the TGA data. The temperature dependent PXRD patterns further confirm that desolvated framework keeps crystalline nature until 250°C, though the diffraction peaks were slightly broaden and shifted. After gas sorption, 1a still exhibits a moderately high crystalline nature, indicating that 1a displays a permanent porous structure.

To check the selective adsorption properties of 1a, hydrogen and nitrogen adsorptions were carried out at 77K; carbon dioxide, methane, and acetylene adsorptions were carried out at 273K and 296K, respectively. As shown in  , 1a can take up a relatively significant amount of hydrogen (24.4cm3/g) but a negligible amount of nitrogen (2.3cm3/g) at 77K and 1atm, underlying a good capacity of 1a for H2/N2 separation . 1a can also absorb 23.3cm3/g acetylene and 23.0cm3/g carbon dioxide, but a very limited amount of methane (7.3cm3/g) at 273K and 1atm ( ). Their adsorption isotherms at 296K (Fig. S6) further confirmed the different gas uptakes of 1a for these examined gas molecules, underlining the potential of these new MOFs for the selective gas separation of C2H2/CH4, CO2/CH4.

The coverage-dependent adsorption enthalpies of 1a to carbon dioxide, acetylene, and methane were calculated based on the virial method, a well-established and reliable methodology from fits of their adsorption isotherms at 273K and 296K (Fig. S7) . The enthalpies at zero coverage of gas were calculated to give the values of 38.3, 34.7, and 28.6kJ/mol for C2H2, CO2, and CH4 respectively. The adsorption enthalpies for C2H2, CO2, and CH4 in 1a are moderately higher than those reported values . The relatively high Qst  of this compound may be due to the pore size and open metal sites in the activated framework, which favors the selective gas separation for these large gas molecules. Henry's law selectivities (Sij ) for C2H2/CH4, CO2/CH4 calculated respectively based on the equation Sij  = KHi /KHj , are also shown in Table S1, which are moderately high .

The X-ray diffraction data was collected using synchrotron radiation, λ=0.40663Å, at Advanced Photon Source on beamline 15ID-C. Indexing was performed using APEX2 (difference vectors method). Data integration and reduction were performed using SaintPlus 6.01. Absorption correction was performed by multi-scan method implemented in SADABS. The structure was solved using SHELXL-2014 (direct methods) and refined using SHELXL-2014 (full-matrix least-squares on F2) contained packages. Despite of using synchrotron source and trying several crystals from different batches, diffraction experiment resulted in low quality diffraction data. This can be attributed to the presence of the solvent disorder and to the presence of bad quality, multiply twinned crystals. All non-H atoms were found in the difference Fourier map and were refined using the distance restraints. Hydrogen atoms were placed in geometrically calculated positions and included in the refinement process using riding model with isotropic thermal parameters: Uiso(H)=1.2Ueq(-CH). The DEF solvents could not be located. Contributions to scattering from all solvent molecules were removed using the SQUEEZE routine of PLATON; the structure was then refined again using the data. Crystal data for 1: CuC17H11O5, Mr=358.80, monoclinic, space group C2/c, a=17.714(7) Å, b=12.567(5) Å, c=25.643(9) Å, α=90° β=93.440(6) γ=90° V=5698(4) Å3, Z=8, Dc=0.836gcm-3, μ=0.412mm-1, T=100(2) K, 33107 reflections measured, 2465 independent reflections, final R1[I>2σ(I)]=0.1194, wR(F2)=0.2953, GOF=1.074.

decomposition temperature.type: loss of free DEF and coordinated water molecules
